title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "Cauldshouthers is a name as familiar to me as Oliver Castle, orDrochel, or Neidpath, or Drumelzier."

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Here then I came, for theplace was high and lonesome, and with a few paces I could come to thetop of the Little Scrape and see the whole vale of Tweed fromDrummelzier to Neidpath.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: It wasscarce possible to see far before, but the outlines of the gorge ofNeidpath fleeted through the drift, whence the river issued.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: It was a grateful change to escape from the suninto the coolness of the Neidpath woods; but even there a change wasseen, for the ferns hung their fronds wearily and the moss had lost allits greenness.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The dwelling was white and square, with a beacon toweron the top, which once flashed the light from Neidpath to Drochil whenthe English came over the Border.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: One Sunday morning, he was posting up by Neidpath at a great pace, the country people trooping into the town to church.

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: >age 197, Note 300.— The Duke of Queensberry stripped his domains of Druralanrig,  in Dumfries-shire, and Neidpath in Peebles-shire, of all the wood sit for being cut, in order to enrich the Countess of Yarmouth, whom he supposed to be his daughter.

title: Kriegspiel: the War-Game. [A novel.]
author: Groome, Francis Hindes
snippet: " I am like the Maid ofNeidpath," she once said to him, " that old Lady Glemham used to tell me about.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: For one thingit was a bonnie country-side, all the way from where the waterwashed by auld Neidpath, to Biggar, and for another the roadwas gude, albeit naught but a track ower the moor: but I thinkthe bonniest bit of all that I saw, was when I turned aboutaboon the way to Manor W'ater, and looked past NeidpathTower, and saw a blink of Peebles through the trees, where itlay dozing in the sun.
